key_issues: The legality of abandoning an opposition to a trademark registration under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 is a key issue in this case.
The interpretation of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules 2017, particularly the time frame for submitting evidence in support of opposition, is crucial to the outcome of the case.
The requirement for the opponent to either submit evidence or intimate to the Registrar that they do not desire to adduce evidence, as per Rule 45(1), is a critical aspect of the case.
The implications of deeming an opposition to have been abandoned under Rule 45(2) when the opponent fails to take action within the prescribed time frame is a significant issue.
The role of the Registrar of Trademarks in determining whether an opposition has been abandoned and allowing the application for registration to proceed is an important consideration.
The potential impact of the abandonment of an opposition on the applicant's right to register their trademark is a key issue in the case.
The application of the principles of natural justice and fairness in the context of trademark opposition proceedings is a relevant legal issue.
The interplay between the Trade Marks Act 1999 and the Trade Marks Rules 2017 in governing trademark opposition proceedings is an important aspect of the case.
The burden of proof on the opponent to establish their case and the consequences of failing to do so is a significant legal issue in this matter.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. vs. The Registrar of Trademarks & Anr.**

**Background:**
The case involves a trademark opposition proceeding under the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The respondent, M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt. Ltd. (Respondent 2), filed an application for registration of the trademark "LIVGUARD ZING" for batteries, inverters, and similar goods on July 11, 2014. The application was published in the Register of Trade Marks on February 15, 2016, inviting opposition. On June 2, 2016, the appellant, M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd., filed a notice of opposition before the Registrar of Trade Marks. The respondent filed a counterstatement on March 7, 2018, which was served electronically on the appellant on the same day.

**Legal Issues:**
The primary issue in this case is the interpretation of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, which deals with evidence in support of opposition. The rule requires the opponent to either submit evidence by way of affidavit or intimate to the Registrar and the applicant that they do not desire to adduce evidence, within two months from the service of the counterstatement. The opponent's failure to take action within the specified timeframe results in the opposition being deemed abandoned.

**Arguments:**
The appellant argued that they were not required to submit evidence or intimate their intention not to adduce evidence, as the expression "leave with the Registrar" in Rule 45 is unclear and does not provide a clear procedure for submission of evidence. The respondent, on the other hand, argued that the appellant's failure to submit evidence or intimate their intention not to adduce evidence within the specified timeframe resulted in the opposition being deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2).

**Court Findings:**
The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, presided by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, observed that Rule 45 is "very unhappily worded" and that the expression "leave with the Registrar" is unclear. The court noted that Rule 8 of the Trade Marks Rules deals with the "leaving of documents" and provides a clear procedure for submission of documents to the Trade Marks Registry.

**Decision:**
The court ultimately held that the appellant's opposition was deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2) due to their failure to submit evidence or intimate their intention not to adduce evidence within the specified timeframe. The court ordered that the application for registration of the trademark "LIVGUARD ZING" shall proceed further as per the rules, with no order as to costs.

**Conclusion:**
The case highlights the importance of clarity in legislative drafting, particularly in procedural rules. The unclear language in Rule 45 led to confusion and disputes between the parties. The court's decision emphasizes the need for parties to adhere to the procedural requirements under the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, to avoid abandonment of their opposition.

2. 
Given the nature of the controversy in the present case, it is not 
necessary to enter into the specifics of the application seeking 
registration.  
 
3. 
Suffice it to state that the application for registration was filed 
by Respondent 2 on 11th July 2014, and was published in the Register 
of Trade Marks on 15th February 2016 inviting opposition and that, on 
2nd June 2016, notice of opposition was filed by the appellant before 
the learned Registrar.  Counter statement, in response to the notice of 
opposition filed by the appellant was filed by the Respondent 2 on 7th 
March 2018.  It is an admitted position that, on the same day i.e., 7th
 
 
March 2018, the notice of counter statement filed by Respondent 2 
was served electronically on the appellant.  
4. 
Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules reads thus: 
“45. 
Evidence in support of opposition.— (1) Within two 
months from  service of a copy of the counterstatement, the 
opponent shall either leave with the Registrar, such evidence by 
way of affidavit as he may desire to adduce in support of his 
opposition or shall intimate to the Registrar and to the applicant in 
writing that he does not desire to adduce evidence in support of his 
opposition but intends to rely on the facts stated in the notice of 
opposition. He shall deliver to the applicant copies of any evidence 
including exhibits, if any, that he leaves with the Registrar under 
this sub-rule and intimate the Registrar in writing of such delivery. 
 
If an opponent takes no action under sub-rule (1) within the 
time mentioned therein, he shall be deemed to have abandoned his 
opposition.” 
 
 
5. 
At a plain glance, Rule 45 is very unhappily worded. It uses the 
expression “leave with the Registrar”. This is an expression to which 
Digitally Signed

Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137

                                                       Page 3 of 9  
 
   
no legal interpretation can possibly be given.  
 
6. 
My attention has been invited to Rule 8 of the Trade Mark 
Rules which deals with “leaving of documents” etc. and reads thus: 
“8. 
Leaving of documents, etc.— All applications, notices, 
statements or other documents or any fees authorised or required 
by the Act or the rules to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or 
to the Trade Marks Registry in relation to a trademark on the 
Register of trademarks on the notified date or for which an 
application for registration is pending on, or is made on or after the 
notified date, shall be made, served, left or sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry: 
 
Provided that the Registrar may, by notification in the journal, 
permit the filing of certain forms or documents, other than the 
application for the registration of a trademark in any other office of 
the Trade Marks Registry.” 
 
7. 
Unfortunately, Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules is just as 
nebulous as Rule 45.  It requires the opponent, opposing the 
registration of a trade mark, to “leave with the Registrar”, evidence by 
way of affidavit.  It is difficult to understand the expression “leave 
with the Registrar”.  At any rate, it is not an expression which should 
ordinarily find place in a legislative document. 
 
8. 
The case of the appellant, as argued by Ms. Bhabna Das, 
learned Counsel for the appellant, and as set out in the present appeal, 
is that 7th May 2018 being the last date by which the evidence in 
opposition was required to be filed by the appellant, attempts were 
made to upload the evidence on the website of the Registrar of Trade 
Marks, but that, as the website was non-functional, this could not be 
done.  As a result, submits Ms. Bhabna Das, the evidence was sent to 
the office of the Registrar by courier.  It is an admitted position that 
the evidence in opposition as sent by the appellant was, in fact, 
received by the office of the learned Registrar on 10th May 2018, i.e., 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 4 of 9  
 
   
mere three days beyond the last date for “leaving” of the evidence.  
 
9. 
As is apparent, the impugned order has proceeded on the 
premise that, as the evidence in terms of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark 
Rules had not been filed within two months from the service of the 
counter statement of Respondent 2 on the appellant, the opposition of 
the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned by application of 
sub-rule (2) of Rule 45.  
 
10. 
At a bare glance, the impugned order is incorrect, as Rule 45(1) 
does not use the expression “filed”.  What Rule 45(1) requires is that 
the evidence must be “left with the Registrar”.  Where the statute is 
ambiguous, the benefit of ambiguity has to go to the citizen. This 
would be especially so where the statute confers a valuable 
commercial right on the citizen. It cannot be gainsaid that, having 
submitted the notice of opposition, opposing the application of 
Respondent 2 for registration of the Trade Mark, the tendering of 
evidence in support of the opposition was a valuable commercial right 
which enured in favor of the opponent/appellant. There is no 
conceivable reason as to why, having filed the notice of opposition, 
the appellant would abandon the opposition.  That the appellant did 
not, in fact, do so, is manifest by the fact that, on 28th
 
 August 2018, 
the appellant filed an application for extension of time, purportedly 
under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the 
Trade Mark Rules, in Form TM-M, as required by the said rules.  
11. 
The application has not been considered by the learned Deputy 
Registrar while passing the impugned order. In the application, it was 
specifically submitted that the website of the learned Registrar of 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 5 of 9  
 
   
Trade Marks was non-functional on 7th May 2018, as a result of 
which, on 8th
 
 May 2018, the evidence in opposition was sent by the 
appellant by courier.  
12. 
As already noticed, it is an admitted position that the evidence 
in opposition was indeed received by the office of the learned 
Registrar on 10th
 
 May 2018.     
13. 
The issue before the court is whether, in these circumstances 
and in the backdrop of the existing statutory scenario as contained in 
the Trade Marks Act and Trade Marks Rules, this Court should sustain 
the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar, vide the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018, to treat the opposition filed by the appellant, 
to the application of Respondent 2 seeking registration of the 
“LIVGUARD ZING” mark, as having been abandoned.  
14. 
Having heard Ms. Bhabna Das, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Jithin M George, learned Counsel for Respondent 2, 
in my considered opinion, the answer to this query has necessarily to 
be in the negative.  
 
15. 
Two issues would arise for consideration. The first is whether 
there was, in fact, delay on the part of the appellant in complying with 
the requirement of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules. The second is 
whether, assuming there was any such delay, the learned Registrar 
was empowered to condone the delay or to extend the time for 
compliance with Rule 45.  
 
16. 
Addressing the first issue first, Rule 45 (1) stipulates that, 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 6 of 9  
 
   
within two months from service of the copy of the counter statement 
filed by the trade mark applicant, the opponent opposing the 
registration of the mark is required to leave, with the Registrar, 
evidence by way of affidavit in support of the opposition.  Rule 45(1) 
further requires the opponent to the registration of the trade mark to 
deliver, to the applicant seeking registration, copies of the affidavit 
left with the Registrar and to intimate the Registrar in that regard.   
 
17. 
Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules states that all documents, which 
are required “to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or to the Trade 
Marks Registry”, in respect of a Trade Mark in respect of which an 
application seeking registration is pending, “shall be made, served, 
left, or sent or paid to the appropriate office of the Trade Marks 
Registry”. 
 
18. 
As already observed, the provision is as nebulous as can be.  
The Rule, envelops, in one parenthesis, the expressions “made” 
“served”, “left”, “sent” and “paid” and refers to such making, serving, 
leaving, sending, or paying “to the appropriate office of the Trade 
Marks Registry”. 
 
19. 
Given the nature of these provisions and the fact that they affect 
a valuable right vested in an opponent who seeks to oppose the 
registration of a trade mark, I am of the considered opinion that, in the 
facts of the present case, the appellant won’t be entitled to the benefit 
of the ambiguity inherent in this provision.  
 
20. 
The appellant, in its application seeking extension of time as 
filed before the learned Deputy Registrar, as well as in the present 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 7 of 9  
 
   
appeal, has stated, on affidavit, that the attempts at e-filing of the 
evidence in support of the appellant’s objections, on 7th
 
 May 2018, 
could not succeed as the website of the learned Registrar of Trade 
Marks was non-functional.  The impugned order does not seek to 
discountenance this assertion.  Notice was issued in the present 
appeal, and there is no affidavit filed by way of response, denying this 
fact.  
21. 
There is no reason, therefore, for this Court to disbelieve the 
appellant and presume that, in fact, no attempt was made by the 
appellant to e-file the objections on 7th May 2018, especially as, on the 
very next day i.e., 8th May 2018, the objections were in fact sent by 
courier.  This is not, therefore, a case in which the appellant exhibited 
any callous or negligent indolence.   The fact that, on 8th May 2018, 
the appellant did indeed courier the evidence in support of the 
opposition to the office of the learned Registrar of Trade Marks, 
compels this Court to believe the assertion, in the present appeal, also 
contained in the application for extension of time filed before the 
learned Registrar with the evidence in support of the opposition was in 
fact forwarded to the office of the learned Registrar electronically on 
7th
 
 May 2018, but that the attempt could not succeed as the website 
was non-functional.  
22. 
Such an attempt, in my view, would fall within the broad 
embrace of the expression “made, served, left, sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry”, as employed in Rule 
8 of the Trade Marks Rules.  
 
23. 
Even otherwise, it is well-settled that, while procedural 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 8 of 9  
 
   
provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late, 
especially as, prima facie, the appellant did make efforts to “leave” the 
evidence in support of the opposition with the office of the learned 
Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.  
26. 
Resultantly, the learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take into 
account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a 
view thereon.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 9 of 9  
 
   
27. 
I am informed that, after the impugned order was passed, the 
mark of Respondent 2 has proceeded to registration.  
 
28. 
Needless to say, in view of the decision taken today, the 
registration of the Trade Mark shall remain subject to the outcome of 
the view to be taken by the learned Deputy Registrar on the opposition 
filed by the appellant.  
 
29. 
In order that equities are not unnecessarily prejudiced, the  
learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take a decision on the 
appellant's notice of opposition, after following due process in that 
regard, within a period of three months from today.  
 
30. 
For this purpose, both sides are directed to present themselves 
before the office of the learned Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on 
16th
 
 January 2023 at 11:00 a.m. 
31. 
The learned Deputy Registrar would proceed with the matter 
with all due expedition.  
 
32. 
Both sides are directed not to seek any adjournment from the 
learned Deputy Registrar. 
 
33. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no order as to 
costs.  
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
JANUARY 6, 2023

The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022) filed by M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. against the Registrar of Trade Marks and M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt. Ltd.

The appeal was filed against an order dated January 6, 2023, passed by the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, which deemed the opposition to the registration of the trademark "LIVGUARD ZING" to be abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017. The opposition was initially filed by M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. on June 2, 2016, in response to the application for registration filed by M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt. Ltd. on July 11, 2014.

The court noted that the counter statement was filed by M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt. Ltd. on March 7, 2018, and served electronically on M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. on the same day. However, M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. did not file any evidence in support of their opposition within the prescribed time, and therefore, their opposition was deemed to be abandoned.

The court relied on Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules, which states that if an opponent takes no action within the prescribed time, they shall be deemed to have abandoned their opposition. The court observed that Rule 45 is "unhappily worded" but ultimately held that the opposition was indeed abandoned. (Source: PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", page 1-2 of 9)

According to the PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case of M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd (Appellant) vs. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr. (Respondents) with Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000137 and C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022. 

The case revolves around the opposition to the registration of a trade mark. The appellant's evidence in opposition was required to be filed by May 7, 2018, but due to the non-functionality of the Registrar's website, it was sent by courier and received by the Registrar's office on May 10, 2018, three days beyond the deadline.

The Registrar deemed the opposition abandoned as the evidence was not "left with the Registrar" within the stipulated time frame, as per Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules. However, the appellant argued that the term "leave with the Registrar" is ambiguous and that they had not abandoned the opposition, as evident from their subsequent application for an extension of time on August 28, 2018.

The court noted that the impugned order was incorrect, as Rule 45(1) requires the evidence to be "left with the Registrar", not "filed". The court also held that the benefit of ambiguity should go to the citizen, especially when a valuable commercial right is involved. The case highlights the importance of clarifying ambiguous language in legislative documents to avoid confusion and ensure fair proceedings. (Source: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf)

The appellant's counsel, Ms. Bhabna Das, argued that the evidence was sent on time, but the website's non-functionality prevented timely upload. My attention has been invited to Rule 8 of the Trade Mark 
Rules which deals with “leaving of documents” etc. and reads thus: 
“8. 
Leaving of documents, etc.— All applications, notices, 
statements or other documents or any fees authorised or required 
by the Act or the rules to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or 
to the Trade Marks Registry in relation to a trademark on the 
Register of trademarks on the notified date or for which an 
application for registration is pending on, or is made on or after the 
notified date, shall be made, served, left or sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry: 
 
Provided that the Registrar may, by notification in the journal, 
permit the filing of certain forms or documents, other than the 
application for the registration of a trademark in any other office of 
the Trade Marks Registry.”

nebulous as Rule 45.  It requires the opponent, opposing the

with the Registrar”.  At any rate, it is not an expression which should 
ordinarily find place in a legislative document.

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "36. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the court case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022 involves M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd (Appellant) and The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr. (Respondents). The impugned order deemed the appellant's opposition to be abandoned due to non-filing of evidence within two months. However, the court notes that Rule 45(1) of the Trade Mark Rules requires evidence to be "left with the Registrar", not "filed". The appellant had submitted evidence just three days beyond the deadline. On August 28, 2018, the appellant filed an application for extension of time, which was not considered by the Deputy Registrar. The court argues that the opposition was a valuable commercial right and the appellant had no reason to abandon it. (Source: PDF page 4)

9. 
As is apparent, the impugned order has proceeded on the 
premise that, as the evidence in terms of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark 
Rules had not been filed within two months from the service of the 
counter statement of Respondent 2 on the appellant, the opposition of 
the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned by application of 
sub-rule (2) of Rule 45.  
 
10. 
At a bare glance, the impugned order is incorrect, as Rule 45(1) 
does not use the expression “filed”.  What Rule 45(1) requires is that 
the evidence must be “left with the Registrar”.  Where the statute is 
ambiguous, the benefit of ambiguity has to go to the citizen. This 
would be especially so where the statute confers a valuable 
commercial right on the citizen. It cannot be gainsaid that, having 
submitted the notice of opposition, opposing the application of 
Respondent 2 for registration of the Trade Mark, the tendering of 
evidence in support of the opposition was a valuable commercial right 
which enured in favor of the opponent/appellant. There is no 
conceivable reason as to why, having filed the notice of opposition, 
the appellant would abandon the opposition.  That the appellant did 
not, in fact, do so, is manifest by the fact that, on 28th
 
 August 2018, 
the appellant filed an application for extension of time, purportedly 
under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the 
Trade Mark Rules, in Form TM-M, as required by the said rules.

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard a case (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022) between M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd (Appellant) and The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr. (Respondents). The court considered whether the decision to treat the opposition filed by the appellant as abandoned should be sustained. 

The appellant's evidence in opposition was sent by courier on May 8, 2018, after the Trade Marks website was non-functional on May 7, 2018, and was received by the Registrar's office on May 10, 2018. The issue was whether the appellant's delay in complying with Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules was justified. 

The court considered two issues: whether there was a delay in complying with Rule 45 and whether the Registrar could condone the delay. Rule 45(1) requires the opponent to leave evidence with the Registrar within two months of the counter-statement. The court noted that the provisions were ambiguous, but the appellant's attempts to e-file the evidence on May 7, 2018, were unsuccessful due to the website being non-functional.

The court ultimately decided in favor of the appellant, stating that the decision to treat the opposition as abandoned should not be sustained. The PDF document provides the full details of the case, including the legal arguments and proceedings.

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "36. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the opponent of a trade mark registration must leave evidence in support of the opposition with the Registrar within two months of the counter statement being filed (Rule 45(1)). The opponent must also deliver copies of the affidavit to the applicant and inform the Registrar (Rule 45(1)). Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules states that all documents related to a pending trade mark application must be submitted to the appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry. The court notes that the provisions are ambiguous, but the appellant will not benefit from this ambiguity in this case (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022). The proceedings involve M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd (appellant) and The Registrar of TradeMarks & Anr. (respondent), with advocates Ms. Babna Das, Mr. Mukul Kumar, and Mr. Vizzy George representing the appellant.

registration of the mark is required to leave, with the Registrar, 
evidence by way of affidavit in support of the opposition.  Rule 45(1) 
further requires the opponent to the registration of the trade mark to 
deliver, to the applicant seeking registration, copies of the affidavit 
left with the Registrar and to intimate the Registrar in that regard.

Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules states that all documents, which 
are required “to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or to the Trade

The Rule, envelops, in one parenthesis, the expressions “made”

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision in the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022. The appellant, M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd, opposed the registration of a trade mark by the respondent, The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr. The opposition was filed, but the evidence in support was received three days late. 

The court ruled that the decision of the Deputy Registrar to treat the opposition as abandoned was unfair, as the appellant had made efforts to "leave" the evidence within the stipulated time. The court set aside the impugned order dated August 30, 2018, and directed the Deputy Registrar to take into account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant.

The court also directed the Deputy Registrar to take a decision on the appellant's notice of opposition within three months from January 6, 2023. Both sides were directed to present themselves before the office of the Deputy Registrar on January 16, 2023, and not to seek any adjournment. The appeal was allowed with no order as to costs.

The court's decision was based on the provisions of the Trade Marks Act and Rules, particularly Rule 45(1) of the Trade Marks Rules. The case highlights the importance of adhering to procedural timelines in trade mark opposition proceedings. (Source: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000137)

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "36. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf", the High Court of Delhi ruled in favor of the appellant, M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. The court set aside the impugned order dated August 30, 2018, which treated the opposition as abandoned due to late submission of evidence. The court directed the Deputy Registrar to consider the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant. The decision was made on January 10, 2023, and was digitally signed by Kamla Rawat. The case number is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022, and the Neutral Citation Number is 2023/DHC/000137. The court emphasized that the right to oppose registration of a trade mark is sacrosanct and should not be rigidly interpreted to result in the evisceration of substantive rights vested in citizens.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 8 of 9  
 
   
provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late, 
especially as, prima facie, the appellant did make efforts to “leave” the 
evidence in support of the opposition with the office of the learned 
Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.  
26. 
Resultantly, the learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take into 
account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a 
view thereon.
